19.86.text: Hi, Lucy, nice to meet you.

21.96.text: So I understand that you were referred here by your GP

25.66.text: because you've been feeling quite down recently.

30.16.text: I've been feeling quite bad for quite a while

32.38.text: so I thought maybe it's time to see someone about it

35.52.text: because I don't want to feel like this anymore.

38.04.text:
Okay, so from your notes I saw
that you saw the GP about three months ago.

44.28.text: So how long have you been feeling down all together?

47.54.text: Quite a few months before that as well actually,

50.14.text: but it's gotten pretty bad these past few months

54.22.text: so that's kind of why I came.

56.32.text: Okay, so has it got worse since you saw your GP?

60.76.text: Okay, so tell me how are things at the moment?

64.62.text: Well, I kind of started just feeling a bit low

70.00.text: but I don't know, just recently

73.84.text: I just can't really be bothered to do anything.

76.81.text: I kind of find it hard to get motivated for things.

80.06.text: I want to be, I really want to be better,

82.82.text: but it's just kind of reaching the end now

85.84.text: where I just want to do something about it.

89.16.text: Okay, so you said that you're feeling really down, really sad.

94.36.text: And you feel like you haven't got any motivation.

103.04.text: Okay, and you haven't got any motivation,

105.27.text: but it sounds like you're putting quite a lot of pressure on yourself

108.14.text: to try and feel a bit better.

109.64.text: Yeah, I just, it's kind of hard as well

112.06.text: because there's not really anyone to talk about some.

115.58.text: I just kind of stay on my own trying to.

118.79.text: I don't like to think about it but.

121.48.text: Okay, so you say you've been feeling quite isolated,

126.78.text:
Yeah, there's no one in can talk
to about it.

129.50.text: No one would listen or understand, anyway.

131.66.text:
Okay, so I'm just gonna try and
find out a little bit more about you.

135.06.text: So I understand that you're an English student at uni.

139.56.text: And you live away from home with some friends, is that right?

144.88.text: Okay, so you don't live far from the uni,

148.18.text: but you say you live with your friends

149.78.text: but you don't feel like you can talk to them.

151.65.text: Yeah, I mean they're lovely, I get on really well with them,

156.14.text:
but I don't know, recently
whenever they want to go out or stuff,

161.46.text: I don't want to bring them down.

164.16.text: They don't understand what I'm going through.

166.00.text: They kind of, I don't know, they don't make fun of how I feel

169.36.text: but they don't really understand what it's like.

172.61.text: I don't want to go out with them and bring them down or stuff.

176.74.text:
Okay, so it sounds do you try
and hide the way you're feeling from them?

182.55.text: It's easier to hide it than to try and explain it all the time

185.18.text: when no one really wants to know.

189.00.text: Okay, so it sounds like you've been feeling down,

194.36.text: You feel like you want to be better

196.10.text:
but actually it sounds like you
feel like you can't reach out for help,

200.62.text: No, I don't really talk to my parents about it either.

206.42.text: Okay, I'm just gonna go back in time a little bit.

208.84.text: I suppose I'm just wondering when did all of this start?

211.11.text: You said it's been going on for quite a few months.

213.48.text: Yeah, I guess it kind of started

222.32.text: actually when I was revising for my exams.

226.99.text: I put a lot of stress on myself I think.

229.46.text: I've always wanted to do well for me

231.20.text: and I guess for my parents, so the stress of exams,

235.92.text: and it was also kind of hard because my parents were going

239.24.text: through a bit of a troubled time then so.

242.84.text: Okay, so this would be like last March, last April?

248.78.text: Around that time, so about six months-ish,

251.88.text: and it sounds like a lot was happening.

254.22.text: So you had a lot of uni pressure on

256.70.text: and you said that your parents were having marital problems.

263.43.text: Okay, and it sounds like that was a real shock to you.

267.67.text: Yeah, I guess it was hard as well because

271.12.text: I wasn't doing well at uni and I guess I just felt a bit guilty.

275.61.text: I know it sounds silly but I felt

278.49.text: like maybe if I could do better then they would get better

281.81.text: but it just wasn't really happening.

285.36.text: Okay, so it sounds like you were trying to work hard.

288.58.text: And be more successful because you thought that that would

291.18.text: make them happier and try and fix things.

294.03.text: Yeah, I wanted to make them feel better

296.33.text: but it just kind of backfired a little I guess.

302.70.text: Well, it just ended up with them getting worse

305.71.text: and I've just been feeling worse since then.

309.31.text: Okay, so after the summer, after the exam period,

313.51.text: and how did that exam period go for you in the end?

318.48.text: Okay, that's an awful lot of pressure to put on yourself

321.82.text: that you I suppose to think.

322.68.text: It's just annoying because I know I should have done better

325.82.text: and I just didn't and I guess I beat myself up a lot about it.

332.06.text: So you say I know I should have done better.

336.56.text: I mean I suppose hearing it from my perspective

339.31.text:
I'm thinking it sounds like you
had an awful lot going on at the time.

343.97.text: that you wouldn't do as well as normal.

347.01.text:
I suppose I'm just wondering if
you have very high standards for yourself?

351.52.text: Probably, maybe more than other people.

355.38.text: My parents have always kind of taught me,

358.26.text: in a loving way I guess, but that you should do your best

362.53.text: but also get the best, and I agree with that.

366.67.text: I think that's the right thing to think,

369.11.text: but when I don't do that, I don't know,

373.14.text: it annoys me a lot and I worry that it annoys them.

377.40.text: So it sounds like you feel you should always do your best.

380.95.text: Is that the words you used, yeah,

383.18.text: and that there isn't any kind of exceptions for that but.

387.10.text:
Okay, so I can see then that
that was a really difficult time for you

391.39.text: and that was when your mood started to get lower

394.93.text: and things are still quite bad now.

396.83.text: I mean what's the situation with your parents at the moment?

401.67.text: I think it doesn't sound good.

404.94.text: I don't really talk to them a lot

406.44.text: but I don't think they're going through very good things.

409.70.text: I don't like to talk to them about it

411.94.text: because it just makes me feel worse.

414.98.text: But I don't think it's getting any better.

417.48.text: Were you home over the summer?

421.00.text: Mm hmm, and how was that?

425.38.text: No, it was quite tense all the time.

429.70.text:
It stressed me out more than
relaxed me over the summer I guess.

436.92.text: Okay, so it sounds then like quite a lot has been happening.

440.11.text: You've been feeling very low, you've had uni pressure on,

443.34.text: you've had problems with your parents' marriage

447.08.text:
and sounds like you feel that
you can't really reach out to anyone,

449.75.text:
they can't understand, that you
can't really reach out to your parents right now.

453.79.text: You can't really confide in your friends.

456.49.text: So I suppose I'm just wondering if you can tell me a bit more

458.27.text: about how you've been feeling, say this past week?

462.86.text: Really not good to be honest.

465.80.text: I actually if I don't have to

469.34.text: then I don't really leave the house or get out of bed.

472.88.text: I can't find the motivation for the things I used to join.

476.58.text: I used to love doing sports or going out

479.05.text: and now I just prefer to lie in bed and not really do anything.

484.06.text:
I missed a few lectures this
week that I should have gone to but.

487.36.text: Right, so I suppose I'm just wondering then

490.46.text: let's see if we can think about one thing, say a lecture,

495.73.text: and what kind of thoughts do you have about

497.30.text: going to that lecture before it happens?

499.93.text: I don't really see the point anymore.

502.23.text: If I can't do as well as I should be doing

506.41.text: then what's the point in putting myself in those positions.

512.98.text: I can't be bothered anymore to try.

515.51.text: It just stresses me out more than it needs to.

519.05.text:
Okay, so it sounds like the kind
of thoughts you've got in your head

521.38.text: are it's pointless, it's not worth it.

525.84.text: Do you have any other thoughts in your head

527.44.text: when you're just at that point before you go to the lecture?

531.66.text: So like, I don't know, I don't really even deserve to be here

538.87.text: if I can't do well enough.

540.61.text: I feel these other students are doing well

543.11.text: and doing better and want to be there.

547.55.text: I don't know why I'm here even at uni to be honest.

552.51.text:
So it sounds like you feel like
you're not as good as other people here.

559.40.text: Sorry, is it okay if I take notes as we go through?

561.24.text: It's just I'm trying to I guess understand what you're telling me

564.38.text:
and it helps me just to write it
down and I'll share this with you later.

569.46.text:
Okay, so it sounds like those
are some quite negative thoughts to have.

573.10.text: You're kind of saying it feels like it's pointless,

575.74.text: it's more effort than it's worth and I don't deserve to be here.

580.26.text: I mean when you have those thoughts how do you feel?

585.64.text: Very unworthy probably would be the best way to put it.

590.28.text: Kind of, I don't know, just lower than normal.

598.52.text: The thing it makes me think about

599.96.text: all the things I should have been doing better.

602.53.text:
Okay, so what you described
there when you said I'm unworthy,

606.29.text: I should be doing lots of things better,

608.92.text: those are kind of what I would call thoughts.

611.46.text: Actually I suppose I'm trying to understand what it feels like

614.20.text: in your gut, what kind of emotions.

616.27.text: Do you feel happier, do you feel sad?

619.63.text:
What kind of emotions are you
feeling when you have those thoughts?

630.04.text: A bit of kind of anger and frustration as well.

637.53.text: I noticed when you're kind of telling me this,

639.09.text: and I know this is quite a heavy topic,

643.55.text: and I suppose I wonder a little bit are you a bit,

646.13.text: how do you feel about having these emotions,

655.40.text: I've never yet to talk about it so it's quite uncomfortable

660.93.text:
Okay, well, you're doing a great
job cause I know that this can be difficult.

664.82.text: Okay, so it sounds like some of the thoughts

666.72.text: you are describing are it's pointless,

671.40.text: I don't deserve to be here, I'm unworthy.

674.88.text:
And those kind of thoughts it
sounds like they just flip through your mind

678.98.text: and then you're kind of describing different emotions that those lead to.

682.58.text: You're kind of describing sad, anger, frustration, embarrassed.

685.72.text: What about in your body, what happens?

688.56.text: How do you feel kind of physically?

691.96.text: I used to be I think from those emotions very wound up,

696.30.text: very kind of stressed all the time,

700.10.text: but recently it's just been a lot more draining than anything.

707.62.text: and I just can't be bothered anymore

710.26.text: and my body reflects that, but then when I try and sleep

712.86.text: I just can't seem to have a satisfied night's sleep.

720.53.text: So it sounds like this is affecting you,

721.69.text: it's draining you of your energy

723.72.text: like your body can't be bothered,

725.82.text: I think that's a really good way of describing it,

727.49.text: and you're noting sleep problems as well,

729.33.text: and then what do you do?

731.66.text: So this is say we're back to the point before the lecture.

735.16.text: So you start having these thoughts, these emotions,

737.83.text: and you know your body I guess it sounds like

742.20.text: What then happens? What do you do next?

748.66.text: I kind of focus on the negative thoughts

750.73.text: when I probably should not think about them,

752.89.text:
but I focus on them and then
I don't really want to do anything,

757.79.text: kind of stay in bed or.

759.58.text:
So you think even more about
those kind of worries that you have?

763.18.text: So you do a bit of dwelling and you stay in bed,

767.39.text: and it sounds like you don't,

768.95.text: you haven't tried speaking to your friends about it

771.34.text: No, I don't see the point.

774.78.text: Okay, and then after you've done that,

776.18.text: so after you've not gone to the lecture,

777.80.text: you've stayed in bed, you kind of spent time

779.87.text: as you said focusing on those thoughts,

782.03.text: those negative thoughts, how do you feel after that?

785.16.text: Do you feel better or do you feel worse?

789.00.text: I guess I feel slightly worse

791.64.text: but then a bit numb in a way,

795.82.text:
kind of once you've felt that
cause I do feel tired all the time.

801.26.text: I just try and push it out

803.36.text: and then you don't really think about anything,

805.32.text: and it's almost nicer that way than to

808.66.text: keep focusing on how much you're getting wrong

811.40.text: and how much you can't do stuff.

813.30.text: Sometimes it's better just to not think about it at all.

818.12.text:
So it sounds like in some ways
it's a bit of a relief to do that.

821.96.text:
But in other ways maybe you
think it might make things worse.

824.84.text: Probably in the long run, yeah.
